dialogues.speaker: THE WORST NIGHTMARE IMAGINABLE
dialogues.text: SLOW MOTION: The plane is going down fasts Everyone panic and screams in SLOW MOTION as the oxygen masks away like plastic pendulums. The SOPRANO VOICE continues the prayer ANDREW LARGEMAN (LARGE), 25, is the only passenger who remains unfazed. Even as the flames from the wing echo fi reflections on his cheeks, even as the young mother seate next to him clutches her newborn and wails towards God, e as bags fall from the overhead compartment at half-speed the beverage cart slides down the aisle, Andrew Largeman peacefully; unaffected. He calmly reaches up and turns his air vent so it blows directly on him. He looks up to

A ceiling fan spins above stacks of scripts, a cell phone charging, bare wall and a small human figure dwarfed by the enormous white be which he sleeps. HIS BYES bounce back and forth under their lids as he dre like they're chasing each other in a game of tag. THE PHONE is finally answered by the machine. Large's eye stop moving.

So uh... '(starts to cry) Look, I don't know how to do . this, but you're gonna need to come home now. Last night uh... Your mother died last night, Andrew. She uhh... I'm sorry. I'm so sorry. But she uh... she drowned... last night she drowned in the bath... BEEP. The machine cuts the voice off. LARGE'S EYES processing. They elide slowly left, then back right as if scanning in data. He blinks. He blinks again slowly. His eyelids floa closed. He falls back to sleep.

He moves through the kitchen which is whirling with over thirty people in white: chopping, frying, sauteing, YELLI The Vietnamese chef wears a headset and BARKS ORDERS down line. dialogues.text: Ten resumes just today. They come in everyday from Idaho or Florida or Milwaukee and do you know what they want even more than a guest spot on "Everybody Loves Raymond"? They want your job. This will not happen again. This will never happen again. You have two tables. You are thirty minutes late; if I ever say this again, your job will GO TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

He unwinds the ear piece, pull through the back of his jacket, out the neck and into his ear. Immediately we hear a VIETNAMESE MAN'S VOICE giving orders over the ear piece.

dialogues.text: This is it. She puts on a CD, (the song: "I'm Doing Fine" by Colin Ha SAM (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing fancy, but... (OFF LARGE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?     51 LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uhh... It's Titembay right? SAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's weird, huh? You're so freaked out right now, you're like running for the door. You can go, don't feel bad. LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop doing that. SAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That whole thing you just did. Don't do that. I want to be here, and I wouldn't be here if I didn't want to be, okay? Trust me, my family's way more fucked up then yours, okay? (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay? SAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, Titembay. SAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, he's my brother. LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he adopted? SAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well kind of. My mom adopted him years ago from Sally Strothers. one of those: For the cost of a cup of coffee a day" kind of things. where she's like, "How can you sit there and not help the children?" And we just couldn't. We couldn't sit there and not help those children. So we sent him letters and pictures for years and then I got really into ice skating and we kind of forgot about'em. Then one day the phone rang and it was Titembay and he was at the dry cleaners around the corner and he said that he was going to school at Rutgers and living in the dorms, but since he was used to living with his tribe he'd much rather live with his family.     52 LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. SAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah and he's been here ever since. He's an amazing guy, you gotta hear some of his stories. I mean this guy struggled through so much because he wanted to learn. I think of what he's accomplished and I just feel so lazy. He's studying criminal justice at Rutgers right now and when he was a baby he was one of those kids with flies all over his face. LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. I mean that's great. It's a crazy story. SAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That, my friend, is a true story. I'm not that good- A pause. Sam sits on the bed. THE AWESOKE MUSIC PLAYS. Sh breaks the moment by pulling a small tattered piece of sa fabric off the bed.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CO13T'D)
dialogues.text: This is Tickle. Large sits down next to her. LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is Tickle? SAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tickle is my favorite thing in the whole world. It's all that's left of Nannie... my blanket. LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Tickle is all that remains? SAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was there a hurricane or something? SAM (LAUGHING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut-up. No, I mean I had it since I was born. it was the blanket they brought me home in from the hospital. LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like the Wailing Wall.     53 SAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Wailing Wall. It's like the most holy place for Jews to go and pray in Israel. It's all that's left of this enormous temple that was destroyed by the Romans. SAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow, so you're like really Jewish? Large laughs. SAM (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, you are aren't you? LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I'm not. I mean I'm Jewish, but I'm not really Jewish. I don't do anything Jewish. I don't go to temple or anything. But I don't know any Jews who go to temple. The Jews I know only go on Yom Kippur. One day; the day of repentance. Did you know that most temples are designed with movable walls so that on the one day of the year when ГўВЂВў everyone comes to repent they can actually make the room big enough to hold everyone? SAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't really believe in God. LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just tickle. SAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I believe in Tickle_ They laugh. A nice moment. They hold eye contact. THE AWE MUSIC PLAYS. SAM (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not gonna like make out or anything. LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? SAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I just totally ruined the moment didn't I? LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I wasn't... Г‚ВЂВў     54 SAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just mean we're not gonna like make out. LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. I hadn't planned on... SAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean to put that out there, that was lame. BLAAAAHRH. That was so dumb. You know what I do when I'm feeling completely unoriginal? She stands up and does really weird gestures with her han SAM (CONT'D) LABA-LABA-LABA-LABAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Large states.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT ' D)
dialogues.text: I make a noise or I do something that no one has ever done. And then I feel like... unique again; even if only for a second. LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So no one has ever done that? SAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not in this spot, no. You just witnessed a completely original moment in history. It's refreshing. You try one. LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. SAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Trust me yours was good enough for both of us. SAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. What are you shy? This is your chance to do something that has never, ever been done before and will never be copied throughout human existence. If nothing else, you'll be remembered as the only person who ever did this. He stares at her. She's not gonna let up. Large lifts his index finger in the air and twirlsa it.     55 LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ZzzZzz. Be stares at her. LARGE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was that? SAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I've done that one before. She bursts out laughing. He smiles. SAM (CONT ' t3 ) So I got to bury this hamster before the dogs eat him. You warms help? C'AM' TO:

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SAWS BACKYARD-- DAY
dialogues.text: Rusty leaves fall on a backyard swallowed mostly by an em above-ground swimming pool. Sam carries the shoe box as t walk around behind the pool to reveal

dialogues.speaker: A SMALL GATED PET CEMETERY
dialogues.text: About a dozen large rocks serve as tombstones for differe pets. LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. SAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean this is... SAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. They stand in silence. SAM (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not that we're bad pet owners or anything, it's just that we've had so many of them over the years. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Besides some of these are fish. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not to say fish deserve less than other animals, but moat people just flush them, and we just don't believe in that. I mean the idea of flushing something that had life in it... it just makes me sad, you know? (MORE)     56

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta honor something a little more than that, like "Congratulations, man, you had life. Here's your trophy; a little spot in the ground to hang out in." (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, I'm gonna put Jelly right here next to "Goliath", the Rotweiler Titembay backed over during his driving exam. She kneels down and begins to dig with a small shovel lef nearby. Large sits down next to her and watches her dig. brisk wind makes him hug his knees in for warmth. SAM (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you thinking about? LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now? SAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right now? SAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. A second ago before I asked. LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... Right now I was thinking... I was thinking that I've been going to a lot of these things lately. SAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, dates? LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not dates. This isn't a date. Is this a date? Funerals. SAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Who else died? LARGE (EMBARRASSED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... that's why I'm home actually. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I uh... I haven't even really told you that yet, but uh... yeah my Mom just died. Sam stops digging and stares at him. LARGE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, it's weird to say that out loud: 'My Mom died". And uh... eo that's why I'm home... now.     57 SAM (SHOCKED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry. Oh, God I'm so sorry. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And here I am putting you through another one. I mean not that Jelly's even comes close to your Mom's. .. Although we loved, Jelly-- But still... I'm so sorry. I didn't know. LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's okay. It's okay actually. I'm all right with it. Anyway I think it's what she wanted so.., SAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did she die? Large thinks about that.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT ' D)
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I'm so nosey. Forget I asked, I'm sorry. I just need to shut--up sometimes. LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, its okay. She uh... she drowned actually. Sam's jaw drops. LARGE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My Mom was a paraplegic; she had uh... she was in a wheelchair. She was uh... taking a bath and then I guess she slipped or something. That's what they say. I don't know. But needless to say, she drowned. And so... that's how she died. Sam is speechless. Tears well in her eyes. SAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When? LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was uh... Hmm... Sunday. SAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God. Tears roll down her face. LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a laugh) Why are you crying?     58 SAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, I'm sorry, I'm not usually like this. It's just so sad. It's so tragic. Isn't it? It is. It's like real life tragedy or something. LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, let's change the subject, okay? Let's really bring the focus back to Jelly. I mean what could be ruder than talking about someone else who died while you're in the act of burying a close friend. Sam places the box in the hole she's dug. SAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What should we do? LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well IIve only been to one of these things, (re: the other graves) you appear to be the expert. SAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We usually say something. LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: okay, well I'll go first. I didn't really know you, Jelly. But from what I hear, you were a good pet. Had a little trouble with the wheel... SAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: its not funny. Jelly you were a great pet. Tears roll down her face. SAM (CONT'O)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so, so sorry I forgot to take the wheel out of the cage. I'm so sorry about that. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye. I hope that you liked me. Tears stream down her face as she shovels dirt onto the t shoe box. THE PATTER of the SOIL HITTING the BOX is the o sound we hear as: THE CAMERA CRANES UP above them to a bird's-eye perspecti settling on a final frame that looks down on the whole backyard: the above ground pool, the pet cemetery and in bottom right corner, Sam burying as Large watches.     59

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once again Shiva is in full swing. Large passes through a doorway and begins to hear a COMPUTERIZED SEEPING to the tune of the "ShmaГ‚В°. (A Jew prayer.) He looks to his left to see an electronic Mazooz the door frame. it says The Sharper image" on the bottom. He moves his head back and forth past it's censor and eac time it begins the BEEPING of the Shma anew.

dialogues.speaker: THE LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: A tired looking man in his 50's eating a cookie. TIRED MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avi wants his Bar Mitzvah theme to be musicals. As in Broadway musicals. Can you believe that? Paul's kid's theme was the Meta; I got to do the Elora with Mookie Wilson. Miriam and I were at one last weekend at the Pierre; whole thing was like a winter wonderland... live penguins wearing yalmulkas. Now me, I got to lay out ten grand alone for some asshole to build a barricade of French garbage across the boccie lanes at my tennis club. THE CAMERA PICKS UP LARGE holding a plate of food: as he approaches Cynthia. She sits alone with a big photo album her lap. LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just thinking- (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just thinking you spend you're whole life lusting for anything you don't have. You stress over money and your career, you set your clocks back, you exercise, you wait in line, you paint your house, get depressed, feel better, buy things, take your clothes to the dry cleaner, set your clocks forward and spend your whole life waiting for happiness to arrive in the mail. Then you die and people are really sad, they cry really hard... (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and then they go eat lunch. Hetakes a bite of his bagel. CYNTHIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh please be a little more interesting than that. (MORE)     60

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't be the brooding guy. That's so unoriginal. I'd rather hold onto who I imagined you'd become. LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss me? CYNTHIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Me? LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She didn't like being alive. She got what she wanted. This should be a party. Instead we're supposed to mope. About what? She never did anything. CYNTHIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She made you. LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: some trophy. I do have to say I'm impressed with the turnout. CYNTHIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, you didn't think people would come? LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seems to me the only thing more depressing than a funeral is a funeral where no one shows up. Don't you ever think about who'll show up to yours? CYNTHIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Right now I'm alive, so I think about living. LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's one way to determine who your friends are. The people who'd show up at my funeral if it was held in their state, that's one level of friend. But my real friends, the people who really love me, they'd come if it was on the other side of the country. CYNTHIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So where do I fall into that? LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd be there. CYNTHIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh you think so?     61 LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do. I think you'd show up because the truth is, that you really did miss met you always thought of me as the brother you never had. But you've got too much pride to let me know that. You want to pout 'cause I don't return your calls. CYNTHIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: you're way more talkative than I remember. LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today I've been more talkative than I remember. CYNTHIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about mine? LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funeral? Honestly? I probably wouldn't travel for it- no. But don't worry, I'm sure you'll have a great turnout. CYNTHIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you say that? LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause there's also the guy who lives his life to insure a good turnout. I think that's how my Dad lives his-, like he's sort of writing his own eulogy as he goes and making life choices dependent on how it will sound in a speech. CYNTHIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you implying that that's why I'm going to med school or something? LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just saying a lot of people - not necessarily you - a lot of people try and accumulate accolades that will somehow justify their lives. CYNTHIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's said we spend ninety-five percent of our lives trying to look good. LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do I sign up for not caring?     62 CYNTHIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about sucking it up and really having it out with your Dad? That would be a tremendous step towards not needing to look good. LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow, that was so clever how you did that. Is he grooming you to be a psychiatrist too? Med school's one thing, but please don't become him. CYNTHIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's one of the most caring people I've ever met. LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: well you would say that; you're the son and daughter he never had. Hell, you're the family he never had. Has he got you on Lithium yet? Wait till he does, you'll love him even more. He stands. CYNTHIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet my Mom a dollar you were coming home with a message. I said after nine years, he's definitely coming home with a message. LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: i looked for a message; I got bored and became an actor. He leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Large enters the kitchen where JANICE, 50's, Cynthia's Mo is doing the dishes. He walks over to the counter near th sink and just stares off across the room. She dries her h and moves to Large. She opens her arms. After a beat he s into her embrace. He rests his head on her shoulder and closes his eyes. Neither says a word.

dialogues.speaker: LARGE'S BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Morning sun blasts the entire room. Large site on the edg his bed squinting at pictures:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Large peeks his head around the doorway.     63 LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad? After shutting the door behind himself he' crosses to the dresser and lifts one perfume bottle out from a dozen. He smells the nozzle then brings the bottle with him as he e towards...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bathroom is stark white. A large Jacuzzi tub sits at far end of the room. The faucet drips.

dialogues.speaker: THE MOUTH OF THE FAUCET
dialogues.text: as it wells with water and overflows to DRIP onto the dra Large crosses to the tub and tries to tighten the faucet stop it from dripping. It continues to DRIP. He stares at empty tub.

dialogues.speaker: GIDEON, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Hi. Large jumps around and puts his hand to his chest. LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy shit, you scared the shit out of me. He covertly slips the perfume bottle into his pocket. GIDEON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just wake up? LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. GIDEON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sleep all right? LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... fine. GIDEON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmmm. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't even really been in here for a while. I've been using the one in the hall. Shower pressures awful in there though. It's by no means as good a bathroom as this one is. This one is- well we redid all this. Its uh... (beat, catching himself) This is hard.     64 LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Silence. The FAUCET DRIPS. They avoid eye contact. GIDEON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janice will make you some lunch. LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... good. GIDEON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I guess it's breakfast for you. What time is it? LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Silence. DRIP. DRIP LARGE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I wanted to ask you... I mean if you don't want to talk about this its perfectly fine, but I'm just... GIDEON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I can. I know. I figured you would want to... LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we don't have to do it now. I mean you don't have to do that now. It's just at some point I would... I have some questions. GIDEON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew that you would. Silence. GIDEON (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Occasionally she would hum.., your Mother. Always the same tune and I never knew what the song was. I don't even know if it was a song or if she just made it up - It's funny because it always struck me as so out of character for her and every time she did it... I just always liked it. But I never told her I could hear her because I knew if I ever did she would stop. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She took a bath every night. And she was always very quiet. (MORE)     65

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only thing I would ever hear when I'm in the bedroom was a little splashing of water when she was moving around. And every now and then, her humming. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: so anyway, then usually she would call me when she was done, so I could come and help her out. But this time, that night... she never called. And I just figured she was taking a longer bath or something, but when I called out to her, she didn't answer. So then I uh... When I came in, she was there. LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So she didn't yell or... GIDEON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I didn't hear anything. The TV was on pretty loud. I always watch the weather report before I go to sleep. LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just weird. GIDEON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, it's just that you'd think if someone was really drowning to death they would scream. I mean really scream from the terror of it all, you know? They would splash and scream I would think; I would have thought. GIDEON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would have too, but no. Nothing. (off Large's look) What? LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't take this the wrong way. GIDEON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What ? LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not reading into this, I'm just thinking out loud so don't get UPSET- GIDEON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? No. LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?     66 GIDEON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Its not that. LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just saying did they check? I mean has someone ruled that out? GIDEON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Because they know she drowned, Andrew. LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just saying the facts. GIDEON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I suppose it doesn't even really matter. But I'd be curious to know. I would like to know if that's what happened; just for me. I mean would that surprise you? GIDEON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Yee! LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She made it very clear to everyone she knew that nothing was ever going to make her happy- GIDEON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know! Do you think I don't know?! LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And c'mon let's be honest; she tried it before. GIDEON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut-up! .lust shut your fucking mouth. Large is taken aback. GIDEON (CONT'D) (FIGHTING TEARS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If nothing else will you please just leave, her alone. She's gone. That's it. That's all you get. She died. We will never see her again. She tried very hard, but she just couldn't find it. She could never find it. And I think - I know that she's found it now. I know that. And I know there's a certain amount of guilt that you must feel for the way things unfolded, but it's too late now. (MORE)     67

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I'm asking you, for me, not to do that. Don't... come here and do that. LARGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I deserve to know the truth. GIDEON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to make her crazy. Why? Does that make it easier for you? Tears stream down Gideon's face, He sits down on the toil and cries. GIDEON (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like you want to torture yourself or something! Why would you want to think that? That that happened. Why would you ever want to think that? Large moves closer to his father who SOBS with his head i his lap and his arms over his head. It takes everything L has to reach out his hand and almost touch his father's shoulder, but he doesn't make it and his hand lands on th sink next to him. GIDEON (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
